synthesis:
Literature Summary: The available evidence on mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV suggests that the transmission rate can be significantly reduced with effective interventions. A systematic review and meta-analysis by Ter Schiphorst et al. found that the MTCT rate of HIV-2 among antiretroviral therapy-naïve women was 0.2%, which is notably lower than the rate for HIV-1, highlighting the influence of maternal viral load and CD4 cell count on transmission rates (1). Additionally, a retrospective observational study from the Kermanshah PMTCT program reported a 0% transmission rate among infants born to HIV-positive mothers, underscoring the potential effectiveness of PMTCT programs when properly implemented (6). These findings suggest that with appropriate interventions, the transmission of HIV from mother to child can be minimized, although the exact percentage varies depending on the context and effectiveness of the interventions. TL;DR: The percentage of HIV-positive patients who transmit the virus to their children can be very low, close to 0%, with effective prevention measures. References: 1. Ter Schiphorst E, Hansen KC, Holm M, Hønge BL. Mother-to-child HIV-2 transmission: comparison with HIV-1 and evaluation of factors influencing the rate of transmission. A systematic review. Transactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene. 2021;116(5):399-408. 6. Who, Global and regional trends: Although strides have been made in thehttps://data.unicef.org/topic/hivaids/global-regional-trends/ HIV response, children are still affected by the epidemic.2021.   • [2] Ikechebelu JI, Ugboaja JO, Kalu SO, Ugochukwu EF. The outcome of prevention of mother to child transmission (PMTCT) of HIV infection programme in Nnewi, Southeast Nigeria. Niger J Med. 2011;20:421-425.

article_summaries.title: Mother-to-child HIV-2 transmission: comparison with HIV-1 and evaluation of factors influencing the rate of transmission. A systematic review.
article_summaries.abstract: A review and collection of data on HIV-2 mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) is absent in the literature. This systematic review and meta-analysis aims to provide a pooled estimate of the rate of HIV-2 MTCT and to identify factors influencing the rate of transmission. PubMed and EMBASE were used to identify eligible publications using a sensitive search strategy. All publications until February 2021 were considered; 146 full-text articles were assessed. Observational studies describing the rate of HIV-2 MTCT in a defined HIV-2 infected study population were included. Other publication types and studies describing HIV-1 or dually infected populations were excluded. Nine studies consisting of 901 mother-child pairs in West Africa, France and Portugal were included in the meta-analysis. The pooled rate estimate of HIV-2 MTCT for antiretroviral therapy-naïve women was 0.2% (95% CI 0.03 to 1.47%), considerably lower than that for HIV-1. The levels of maternal HIV RNA and CD4 cell count were positively related to the vertical transmission rate. Maternal HIV-2 infection did not significantly affect perinatal mortality. It was concluded that the vertical transmission of HIV-2 is lower than that of HIV-1. Maternal viral load and CD4 cell count appear to influence the rate of HIV-2 MTCT.
article_summaries.citation: Ter Schiphorst E, Hansen KC, Holm M, Hønge BL. Mother-to-child HIV-2 transmission: comparison with HIV-1 and evaluation of factors influencing the rate of transmission. A systematic review.. Transactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene. 2021;116(5):399-408.
article_summaries.summary:
**Summary:** The article provides evidence that the rate of mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV-2 is 0.2% among antiretroviral therapy-naïve women, which is significantly lower than the transmission rate for HIV-1. Factors such as maternal HIV RNA levels and CD4 cell count were found to influence the transmission rate.

**Study Design:** Systematic review and meta-analysis

**Sample Size:** 901 mother-child pairs

**Study Population:** The study population included HIV-2 infected mother-child pairs from West Africa, France, and Portugal.

**Risk of Bias:** The risk of bias is not explicitly mentioned in the abstract, but potential biases could arise from the exclusion of non-observational studies, HIV-1, and dually infected populations. Additionally, the reliance on published studies may introduce publication bias, and the variation in study settings and populations could affect the generalizability of the findings.

article_summaries.title: Adherence to Antiretroviral Therapy Among HIV-Positive Pregnant Women on followup at Mizan Tepi University Teaching and Tepi General Hospitals, Southwest Ethiopia.
article_summaries.abstract: Background: The introduction of highly active antiretroviral therapy has not only improved longevity in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-infected individuals but in addition has had a significant impact on the rate of mother-to-child transmission of the infection. Objective: To assess antiretroviral therapy adherence among HIV-positive pregnant women on follow-up at antiretroviral therapy clinic of Mizan Tepi University Teaching and Tepi General Hospitals. Methods: A descriptive cross-sectional study was undertaken in antiretroviral therapy clinics of Mizan Tepi University Teaching and Tepi General Hospitals from April to May 2018. Data were collected through face to face interview using structured and pretested questionnaires and analyzed using Statistical Package for Social Sciences version 20. Results: Majority of the patients had good adherence to their antiretroviral therapy, 68 (66.00%). Medication side effects, 12 (34.00%) and forgetfulness and distance of the hospital from home, each accounting 11 (31.00%) were the main reasons for nonadherence among nonadherent patients. Frequency of counseling (P = .000), CD4 count (χ2 = 37.529, P = .000), World Health Organization's clinical stage (χ2 = 17.515, P = .000), stigma (χ2 = 70.426, P = .000), and family support (χ2 = 46.383, P = .000) were found to be associated with patients' medication adherence. Conclusion: The overall patient adherence to antiretroviral therapy in the study facilities was good. Collaborative work among patients, health care organizations, and the public are necessary to tackle the adherence obstacles and enhance patient adherence to the prescribed medication.
article_summaries.citation: Ikechebelu JI, Ugboaja JO, Kalu SO, Ugochukwu EF. The outcome of prevention of mother to child transmission (PMTCT) of HIV infection programme in Nnewi, Southeast Nigeria. Niger J Med. 2011;20:421-425.
article_summaries.summary:
**Summary:** The abstract does not provide specific information on the percentage of HIV-positive patients who transmit the virus to their children. Instead, it focuses on assessing antiretroviral therapy adherence among HIV-positive pregnant women and identifies factors associated with adherence. 

**Study Design:** Descriptive cross-sectional study

**Sample Size:** Not explicitly mentioned in the abstract

**Study Population:** HIV-positive pregnant women attending the antiretroviral therapy clinics at Mizan Tepi University Teaching and Tepi General Hospitals

**Risk of Bias:** Potential risks of bias include self-reported adherence, which may be subject to social desirability bias, and the limited geographical scope of the study, which may affect generalizability. Additionally, the abstract does not mention how participants were selected, which could introduce selection bias.

article_summaries.title: Mother-to-child transmission of HIV.
article_summaries.abstract: The first children with HIV-1 infection were described in 1983. As of 1998, the global HIV epidemic is having a profound impact on the health and survival of children. Almost all HIV infections among young children are due to vertical transmission, and the intrapartum period appears to provide us with a crucial window of opportunity for prevention. Postnatal transmission through breastfeeding also contributes an estimated one third to one half of vertical transmission worldwide. Carefully conducted epidemiologic studies are elucidating the immunologic, virologic, and behavioral factors affecting the risk of HIV-1 transmission from mother to infant and the natural history of HIV disease in perinatally infected children. Transmission of HIV-1 is influenced by many factors, and a high maternal viral load is insufficient to fully explain vertical transmission of HIV-1. Pediatricians and other providers should counsel HIV-infected women about the means available to decrease the risk of HIV transmission to the infant. However, the majority of HIV-infected children are born in the developing world, and a crucial challenge is to identify safe and effective interventions that are feasible in those countries with the most significant HIV burden.
article_summaries.citation: Bulterys M, Lepage P. Mother-to-child transmission of HIV.. Current opinion in pediatrics. 1998;10(2):143-50.
article_summaries.summary:
**Summary:** The abstract does not provide a specific percentage of HIV-positive patients who transmit the virus to their children. Instead, it highlights that almost all HIV infections in young children result from vertical transmission, with postnatal transmission through breastfeeding contributing significantly to this. The abstract emphasizes the importance of understanding various factors that influence transmission and the need for effective interventions, especially in developing countries.

**Study Design:** The abstract refers to "carefully conducted epidemiologic studies," suggesting that the evidence is derived from observational studies that investigate the factors affecting mother-to-child transmission of HIV.

**Sample Size:** The abstract does not specify a sample size.

**Study Population:** The study population includes HIV-infected mothers and their children, with a focus on perinatally infected children. There is an emphasis on populations in the developing world, where the majority of HIV-infected children are born.

**Risk of Bias:** The abstract does not detail specific risks of bias. However, potential biases could stem from observational study designs, such as selection bias, recall bias, and confounding factors that may not be fully accounted for in the analysis. Additionally, the generalizability of findings may be limited due to variations in healthcare access and interventions between developed and developing countries.

article_summaries.title: [Neurological and psychological evolution of adolescents with vertical transmission HIV infection].
article_summaries.abstract:
AIM:
Personal experience in a sample group of children with AIDS vertically transmitted followed from birth to adolescence (out of 56 cases with documented HIV infection, 9 who have reached the age of 13 have been studied) is presented.

METHODS:
The evaluation protocol includes: hematochemical, serological and virological tests to monitor the infectious status, as well as annual EEG, CT/MRI scan to detect anatomical alteration of CNS, neurological examination, intelligence test (WISC-R), interview and projective test (Blacky Pictures) to investigate emotional situation.

RESULTS:
As to the status of the disease, according to the CDC classification, 2 patients are asymptomatic, 2 paucisymptomatic, 2 with moderate symptoms, 2 severely symptomatic; 1 patient died due to progressive encephalopathy. Of the 2 severely symptomatic cases, 1 presents cortical atrophy and the other basal nuclei calcifications. No one of them has clinical signs of encephalopathy. All patients receive anti-retroviral medications. From tests and interviews emotional problem-emerge, future is seen as menacing and insidious, and defensive mechanisms are fragile and inconstant; denial can lead to a refusal of the pharmacological therapy; families themselves often refuse medical staff the consent to communicate the diagnosis fearing that this could induce unbearable anguish.

CONCLUSIONS:
It seems important that patients are informed, considering their capacity to make front to the communication, even if one must bear in mind that understanding and accepting the diagnosis may be a long and painful process requiring a long time.
article_summaries.citation: Piazza F, Maccabruni A, Rossi G, Chiappedi M, Caselli D, Bonforte F, Lanzi G. [Neurological and psychological evolution of adolescents with vertical transmission HIV infection].. Minerva pediatrica. 2004;56(4):411-7.
article_summaries.summary:
**Summary:** The abstract does not provide specific data on the percentage of HIV-positive patients who transmit the virus to their children. Instead, it presents personal experience with a sample of children who acquired HIV through vertical transmission and were followed from birth to adolescence. The focus is more on the clinical status, treatment, and emotional well-being of the children rather than transmission rates.

**Study Design:** The study appears to be a longitudinal observational study, as it follows a cohort of children with vertically transmitted HIV from birth to adolescence.

**Sample Size:** The study involves 56 cases with documented HIV infection, but the detailed findings pertain to 9 children who have reached the age of 13.

**Study Population:** The study population consists of children with HIV acquired through vertical transmission, followed from birth to adolescence.

**Risk of Bias:** The risk of bias may be present due to the small sample size and the focus on a specific cohort of children who reached a certain age. Additionally, the study seems to rely heavily on personal experience and qualitative assessments, which may introduce subjective bias. The lack of a control group and details on how the sample was selected also contribute to potential bias.

article_summaries.title: Disclosure of HIV serostatus among pregnant and postpartum women in sub-Saharan Africa: a systematic review.
article_summaries.abstract: Disclosure of one's HIV status can help to improve uptake and retention in prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV services; yet, it remains a challenge for many women. This systematic review evaluates disclosure rates among pregnant and postpartum women in sub-Saharan Africa, timing of disclosure, and factors affecting decisions to disclose. PubMed and EMBASE databases were searched to identify relevant studies published between January 2000 and April 2014. Rates of HIV serostatus disclosure to any person ranged from 5.0% to 96.7% (pooled estimate: 67.0%, 95% CI: 55.7%-78.3%). Women who chose to disclose their status did so more often to their partners (pooled estimate: 63.9%; 95% CI: 56.7%-71.1%) than to family members (pooled estimate: 40.1; 95% CI: 26.2%-54.0%), friends (pooled estimate: 6.4%; 95% CI: 3.0%-9.8%), or religious leaders (pooled estimate: 7.1%; 95% CI: 4.3%-9.8%). Most women disclosed prior to delivery. Decisions to disclose were associated with factors related to the woman herself (younger age, first pregnancies, knowing someone with HIV, lower levels of internalized stigma, and lower levels of avoidant coping), the partner (prior history of HIV testing and higher levels of educational attainment), their partnership (no history of domestic violence and financial independence), and the household (higher quality of housing and residing without co-spouses or extended family members). Interventions to encourage and support women in safely disclosing their status are needed.
article_summaries.citation: Tam M, Amzel A, Phelps BR. Disclosure of HIV serostatus among pregnant and postpartum women in sub-Saharan Africa: a systematic review.. AIDS care. 2015;27(4):436-50.
article_summaries.summary:
**Summary:** The abstract does not provide direct evidence regarding the percentage of HIV-positive patients who transmit the virus to their children. Instead, it focuses on the rates and factors influencing the disclosure of HIV status among pregnant and postpartum women in sub-Saharan Africa. The findings suggest that HIV serostatus disclosure is crucial for the uptake and retention of prevention of mother-to-child transmission services, but the actual transmission rates are not discussed in this abstract.

**Study Design:** Systematic review

**Sample Size:** Not specified in the abstract

**Study Population:** Pregnant and postpartum women in sub-Saharan Africa

**Risk of Bias:** The risk of bias is not directly addressed in the abstract. However, potential biases could include publication bias, selection bias due to the inclusion criteria for studies, and reporting bias in the original studies included in the review. Additionally, the variability in disclosure rates suggests possible heterogeneity in study methods or populations.

article_summaries.title: Prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV in Kermanshah, west of Iran from 2014 to 2021.
article_summaries.abstract:
BACKGROUND:
This study aimed to evaluate the implementation of the prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) of the HIV-PMTCT program in Kermanshah, west of Iran, from 2014 to 2021.

METHODS:
The data of all HIV-infected mothers and their infants who were monitored by the Kermanshah behavioral diseases counseling center was extracted and recorded in a checklist.

RESULTS:
Out of 95 included infant, 45 (47.4%) were girls and 50 (52.6%) were boys. The mothers were mostly infected with HIV via their infected spouse. The pregnancies of 77 cases (82.1%) were in accordance with the national guideline. The average length of treatment for this group was 185 days. Of the 18 mothers who did not receive treatment, nine were diagnosed during childbirth and nine had no available information. All infants born from infected mothers underwent after-birth-antiretroviral prophylaxis, and all remained healthy. There was no statistically significant relationship between the birth weight and height of neonates with maternal age, maternal last viral load, disease stage, education, and maternal CD4 levels. Only a statistically significant relationship was observed between the duration of treatment and the infants' weight.

CONCLUSION:
The results suggest the feasibility and effectiveness of the PMTCT program for HIV-positive mothers in Kermanshah. It seems that if pregnant HIV-positive women are diagnosed early and covered by a good prevention program on time, the risk of HIV to their babies will be reduced, significantly.
article_summaries.citation: Who, Global and regional trends: Although strides have been made in thehttps://data.unicef.org/topic/hivaids/global-regional-trends/ HIV response, children are still affected by the epidemic.2021
article_summaries.summary:
**Summary:** The study reports that none of the infants born to HIV-positive mothers in the Kermanshah PMTCT program transmitted the virus to their children. This indicates a 0% transmission rate among the study population, highlighting the effectiveness of the PMTCT program when implemented correctly.

**Study Design:** Retrospective observational study

**Sample Size:** 95 infants born to HIV-positive mothers

**Study Population:** HIV-infected mothers and their infants monitored by the Kermanshah behavioral diseases counseling center in Iran from 2014 to 2021

**Risk of Bias:** The study may have selection bias as it only includes cases monitored by a specific counseling center, which may not represent all HIV-positive mothers in the region. Additionally, there is potential reporting bias due to reliance on recorded data, and information bias from missing data on mothers who did not receive treatment.
